revision.text:
{{Infobox organization |name = |logo = Spectacled Bear Conservation Society Logo.jpg |logo_size = 200px |type = [[Non-profit organization]] |founded_date = 2006 |founder = |location = |location_country = [[Peru]] |area_served = |origins = | key_people = *Robyn Appleton, (founder and research director) *Javier Vallejos Guerrero, (field team leader) |focus = [[Spectacled bear]] conservation |method = |revenue = |num_volunteers = |owner = |Non-profit_slogan = Research. Education. Community Outreach. |homepage = [http://sbc-peru.org/ sbc-peru.org] |dissolved = |footnotes = }}
The '''Spectacled Bear Conservation Society - Peru''' ('''SBC''') is a team of researchers and [[conservationists]] working to study and protect the [[endangered]] [[spectacled bear]] (''Tremarctos ornatus''), also known as the [[Andean]] bear. Spectacled bears are the only surviving species of bear native to South America, and the only surviving member of the subfamily [[Tremarctinae]], the short-faced bears. Their range is the Andean Mountains from Venezuela to Chile.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.bearplanet.org/spectacledbear.shtml |title = Spectacled Bears |publisher = Bear Planet}}</ref>
==History==
The organization began in 2006 when Canadian conservation biologist Robyn Appleton recognized that little research had been done on the spectacled bear. She connected with former hunter turned conservationist Javier Vallejos to go into the field and conduct the first observational study on wild spectacled bears. They discovered the first active maternal den site, and fitted the first wild Peruvian spectacled bear with a GPS collar.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://wildnet.org/expospeakers2015 |title = Wildlife Conservation Expo Guest Speakers 2015 |publisher = [[Wildlife Conservation Network]]}}</ref> The organization was formally established as a Canadian non-profit in 2009.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://threadsofperu.com/the-spectacled-bear-conservation-society |title = Spotlight on: The Spectacled Bear Conservation Society |publisher = Threads of Peru}}</ref>
==Programs==
===Research=== SBC conducts research to better understand the behaviors, range, foraging, mating, dispersal, and reproductive ecology of the spectacled bear. This is done using [[camera trap]]s, [[GPS]]-[[satellite]] collars,<ref>{{cite web |url = http://blogs.sandiegozoo.org/2010/11/29/training-andean-bear-field-crew/ |title = Training Andean Bear Field Crew |publisher = [[San Diego Zoo]]}}</ref> remote video surveillance and collection of genetic samples such as hair.
===Conservation outreach=== SBC staff spends time training local people in research methods and in 2010 the El Centro de Conservación de Batán Grande (Conservation Centre of Batán Grande) was established as a place for local educators and conservationists to conduct workshops and presentations for local villagers. SBC also formed a cooperative of women who live in Batan Grande that produce hand-felted animals to financially assist the local community as well as connect it with the conservation efforts.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://threadsofperu.com/the-spectacled-bear-conservation-society |title = Spotlight on: The Spectacled Bear Conservation Society |publisher = Threads of Peru}}</ref> In October 2015 Robyn Appleton representing the Spectacled Bear Conservation Society - Peru, was a featured guest speaker at the annual [[Wildlife Conservation Network]] Expo.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://wildnet.org/expospeakers2015 |title = Wildlife Conservation Expo Guest Speakers 2015 |publisher = [[Wildlife Conservation Network]]}}</ref>
===Protection of habitat=== In part due to SBC's discoveries and outreach efforts, the [[Peruvians|Peruvian]] government established a wildlife refuge, El Parque Arqueológico y Ecológico de Batán Grande which joins another protected park in hopes of extending a [[conservation corridor]].<ref>{{cite web |url = http://elcomercio.pe/ciencias/planeta/parque-batan-grande-peligro-invasion-tierras-extraccion-marmol-noticia-744609 |title = Parque Batán Grande en peligro por invasión de tierras y extracción de mármol |publisher = El Comercio}}</ref>
==See also== {{Portal|Sustainable development|Environment|Ecology}} * [[Spectacled bear]] * [[Wildlife Conservation Network]] * [[Conservation movement]] * [[Environmental movement]] * [[Natural environment]] * [[Sustainability]]
==References== {{reflist|30em|refs=}}
==External links== {{Commons|Tremarctos ornatus}} {{wikispecies|Tremarctos ornatus}} * {{Official website|http://sbc-peru.org}} * [http://wildnet.org/ wildnet.org], [[Wildlife Conservation Network]] website
{{DEFAULTSORT:Spectacled Bear Conservation Society}} [[Category:Organizations established in 2006]] [[Category:International environmental organizations]] [[Category:Endangered species]] [[Category:Wildlife conservation organizations]] [[Category:Conservation projects]]

A '''transboundary river''' is a river that crosses at least one political border, either a border within a nation or an [[international boundary]]. The country of [[Bangladesh]] has the greatest number of these rivers, almost all of which cross international boundaries. ==Transboundary rivers==
{| class="wikitable sortable" !River !Length (km) !Countries |- |[[Brahmaputra River|Brahmaputra]] |2,900 |{{Hs|04}}{{flag|India}}
{{flag|Bangladesh}}
{{flag|China}}
{{flag|Bhutan}} |- |[[Colorado River|Colorado]] |2,333 |{{Hs|02}}{{flag|United States}}
{{flag|Mexico}} |- |[[Danube]] |2,860 |{{Hs|10}}{{flag|Germany}}
{{flag|Austria}}
{{flag|Slovakia}}
{{flag|Hungary}}
{{flag|Croatia}}
{{flag|Serbia}}
{{flag|Romania}}
{{flag|Bulgaria}}
{{flag|Moldova}}
{{flag|Ukraine}} |- |[[Ganges|Ganga]] |2,525 |{{Hs|02}}{{flag|India}}
{{flag|Bangladesh}} |- |[[Mekong]] |4,350 |{{Hs|06}}{{flag|China}}
{{flag|Myanmar}}
{{flag|Laos}}
{{flag|Thailand}}
{{flag|Cambodia}}
{{flag|Vietnam}} |- |[[Nile]] |6,853 |{{Hs|11}}{{flag|Rwanda}}
{{flag|Burundi}}

{{flag|Congo DR}}
{{flag|Tanzania}}

{{flag|Sudan}}

{{flag|Austria}}

{{flag|Liechtenstein}} |- |}
==Transboundary rivers of Bangladesh== [[Bangladesh]] has at least 58 major rivers that enter the nation from [[India]] or [[Myanmar]]. The hydrologic and political effects of rivers that cross significant boundaries are enormous. Rivers have positive effects in that they carry a significant amount of sediment, which aids in building land in [[Estuary|estuarine]] regions. However this sediment raises the height of riverbeds, thereby causing flooding. [[International convention]]s governing water sharing have led to complex political disputes.{{cite journal |ssrn=2193796 |author=Maxwell, Daniel M |date=28 October 2012 |title=Exchanging Power: Prospects of Nepal-India Cooperation for Hydropower Development |journal=Keck Journal of Foreign Affairs, Forthcoming}} India and Bangladesh share 54 common rivers, of which agreement has been reached only on sharing of waters of the river [[Ganges]]. The ''India-Bangladesh Treaty on the Sharing of the Ganges Waters'' was signed on December 12, 1996 and is based on a sharing formula of the flows measured at Farakka, during the lean season each year, from 1 January to 31 May. The 30-year treaty is renewable by mutual consent.{{cite web | url = http://mea.gov.in/foreignrelation/bangladesh.pdf |format=PDF| title =India-Bangladesh Political Relations | accessdate = 2007-12-18 | last = | first = | work = Sharing of River Waters | publisher = Ministry of External Affairs, Government of India, February 2007 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070925125012/http://www.mea.gov.in/foreignrelation/bangladesh.pdf |archivedate = 2007-09-25}} ==See also== * [[Dharla River]] * [[Jaldhaka River]] ==Notes== ==External links== * [http://www.tbpa.net/ Global Transboundary Protected Areas Network] * [http://waterpartners.geo.orst.edu/ Universities Partnership for Transboundary Waters] * [http://webarchive.loc.gov/all/20021009105103/http%3A//www.cec.org/pubs_info_resources/law_treat_agree/transbound_agree/index.cfm?varlan%3Denglish Publication and Information Resources] * [http://www.ppl.nl/index.php?option=com_wrapper&view=wrapper&Itemid=82 Bibliography on Water Resources and International Law].
